journal-meta.journal-title: The American Review of Public Administration

title-group.article-title: Behavioral Implications of Public Service Motivation
title-group.subtitle: Volunteering by Public and Nonprofit Employees

article-meta.aff: 1University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX

author-notes.corresp: Young-joo Lee, University of Texas at Dallas, 800 West Campbell Rd. WT 17, School of Economic, Political and Policy Sciences, Richardson, TX 75080 Email: ylee@utdallas.edu

fn.p: Young-joo Lee is an assistant professor in public affairs at the University of Texas at Dallas. Her teaching and research interests include human resources management in public and nonprofit organizations, volunteering, and government-nonprofit relations. Her research has appeared in such journals as Public Administration Review, International Journal of Sociology and Social Policy, and Voluntary Action.

abstract.p: Research finds the behavioral implications of public service motivation (PSM) in prosocial behaviors such as volunteering, and explains the higher rate of volunteering among public and nonprofit workers with PSM. Although existing research focuses on the link between employee’s PSM and general volunteering, little is known about how workers’ volunteering activities differ across the public, private, and nonprofit sectors. This study examines differences between public and nonprofit employees’ volunteering focusing on the types of organizations where they volunteer. The results indicate distinctive patterns of volunteering between public and nonprofit sector workers: Nonprofit workers are more likely to volunteer in religious and social/community organizations, whereas public workers are more likely to volunteer in educational organizations. The findings of this study call for a more systematic and multifaceted approach to understanding the link between PSM and volunteering.

body.p: Research has shown that, when compared with workers in for-profit firms, employees in the public and nonprofit sectors are motivated by intrinsic rewards such as serving the public rather than material rewards such as salaries and other monetary benefits (Lewis & Frank, 2002; Light, 2002; Mirvis & Hackett, 1983; Perry & Wise, 1990). The early public service motivation (PSM) literature defines this concept as “an individual’s predisposition to respond to motives grounded primarily or uniquely in public institutions and organizations” (Perry & Wise, 1990, p. 368), and suggests that individuals who pursue public service careers are more likely to derive satisfaction from public sector work and less likely to be motivated by extrinsic benefits such as salary (Lewis & Frank, 2002; Pandey & Stazyk, 2008; Perry, 1996). As scholars find motivational similarities between government and nonprofit sector workers, they expand the application of PSM theory to the nonprofit sector (Brewer & Selden, 1998; Francois, 2000; Gabris & Simo, 1995; Houston, 2006). They assert that public and nonprofit organizations are similar in that both have value-oriented missions, multiple stakeholders and outcomes that are not easily measured. Therefore, behaviors between employees of both sectors are more likely to be characterized by PSM than behaviors of for-profit employees (Houston, 2006). Although the nonprofit literature does not use the term PSM, it also acknowledges that “nonprofit workers are much like public sector workers in having more prosocial motivations for doing their job” (Rotolo & Wilson, 2006, p. 24).

The literature suggests that people live out their PSM through their jobs and through prosocial behaviors such as volunteering (Brewer, 2003; Clerkin, Paynter, & Taylor, 2009; Francois, 2000; Houston, 2006). Research indicates that PSM affects work efforts, job satisfaction, organizational commitment, and ethical conducts of employees (Crewson, 1997; Perry & Wise, 1990). More recently, research finds that high PSM also encourages people to engage in ethical behaviors outside the organization (Houston, 2006). Empirical evidence shows that both public and nonprofit employees are more likely to donate their time to charitable organizations than for-profit employees (Brewer, 2003; Light, 2002; Rotolo & Wilson, 2006; Wilson & Musick, 1997). Houston (2006, p. 81) further argues that “engaging in charitable acts is consistent with the theory of PSM” and that the higher likelihood of volunteering among public employees suggests the prominence of PSM in the public sector compared with the private sector. He concludes that “PSM offers an explanation for the giving spirit” (p. 71).

Although exact definitions vary among scholars, the literature suggests that PSM is a multifaceted concept, including various types of intrinsic motivation (Rainey, 1982). As PSM is a multidimensional concept, it is possible that people who gravitate toward jobs in the nonprofit sector may have a somewhat different distribution of PSM dimensions than those who gravitate to jobs in government and that behavioral implications of PSM may also take different patterns. Provided that participation in volunteering is consistent with the notion of PSM, there may be different patterns in public and nonprofit workers’ volunteering. Understanding the difference between government and nonprofit organizations is a particularly timely task as many levels of government are facing a “human capital” crisis. Moreover, as the boundaries between the nonprofit and public sectors are blurring, there is increasing evidence that employees are willing to shift between sectors (Arthur & Rousseau, 1996). Identifying the difference in behavioral implications of PSM between the government and nonprofit sectors will help better understand employees in each type of organization, therefore contribute to better managing them.

This study examines how behavioral implications of PSM diverge between public and nonprofit employment by investigating workers’ participation in volunteering for different types of organizations. The purpose of this study is not to confirm the underlying mechanism that creates motivational differences between the public and the nonprofit workforce. Rather, this study aims to demonstrate public administration scholars how changing a view on PSM-volunteering link will reveal motivational differences between public and nonprofit employees. The study concludes with a discussion on the multifaceted approach to understanding PSM-volunteering link and suggestions for further research.

sec.title: Theory of PSM and Volunteering
sec.p: Twenty years have passed since Perry and Wise (1990) provided a cornerstone in PSM research with their article “The Motivational Bases of Public Service.” According to Perry, Hondeghem, and Wise (2009, p. 3), research on PSM was an “exit from more than a decade of intense criticism” on government bureaucracy. Some of the harsh criticism on public employees was based on the rational choice theory that assumed government bureaucrats pursue self-interest in their jobs. Rational choice theory views bureaucrats as self-interested, budgeting-maximizing agents who serve their own interests, rather than those of citizens. Therefore, public choice theorists emphasize regulation to prevent bureaucrats from acting against their principals’ interests. However, rational choice theory does not provide explanations for public workers’ self-sacrifice, dedication to public interests, or altruism (Vandenabeele, 2007). Contrary to the rational choice theory, PSM theory assumes that public employees are “public servants” who are motivated by an ethic to serve the public (Goodsell, 2003). They are “committed to the public good and characterized by an ethic built on benevolence, a life in service of others, and a desire to affect the community” (Houston, 2006, p. 68). Although the concept of PSM was somewhat exclusively applied to public sector employment in the past, scholars have broadened the definition of PSM as “a general altruistic motivation to serve the interests of a community of people” (Rainey & Steinbauer, 1999, p. 23) and treat PSM as transcending the public sector and characterizing motivations in other areas that involve promotion of public goods (Perry & Hondeghem, 2008). As Brewer and Selden (1998) point out, “PSM is about public-service motivation rather than public-sector motivation” (p. 416).

Although the exact definitions vary among scholars, they agree that PSM is a multifaceted concept. For instance, Perry (1996) categorizes PSM into four dimensions, including commitment to the public interest, attraction to policymaking, compassion, and self-sacrifice. He also proposes a process theory of PSM, which includes rational, normative, and affective dimensions (Perry, 2000). Alternatively, Brewer, Selden, and Facer (2000) divide the concept into four different types including Samaritans, communitarians, patriots, and humanitarians. With PSM being a multidimensional concept, applying the concept to public and nonprofit employees without considering the dynamic variations of PSM may provide a limited view on their behaviors.

The literature also suggests that despite many commonalities between intrinsic motivations between government and nonprofit employees, some differences exist among individuals in each group (Brown, Khagram, Moore, & Frumkin, 2000; Goodin, 2003; Kearns, 1994). As PSM is a multidimensional concept, it is possible that people who gravitate toward jobs in the nonprofit sector may have a somewhat different distribution of PSM dimensions than those who gravitate to jobs in government while both groups show higher levels of PSM than private sector employees. Consequently, the dichotomous approach may ignore the distinctiveness of employee motivation across the sectors and provide an overgeneralized view.

sec.title: Link Between PSM and Volunteering
sec.p: PSM scholars have examined the behavioral implications of PSM by focusing on the extent to which public (and nonprofit) employees engage in behaviors consistent with the theory of PSM (Brewer, 2003; Brewer et al., 1998; Houston, 2006; Rainey, 1982). Research has shown that PSM affects an individual’s behavior both inside and outside of organizational context (Perry & Wise, 1996; Houston, 2006). Along with other kinds of prosocial activities such as donation of money and blood, volunteering is referred to as one of the behavioral consequences of PSM because of its other-directed nature and its outcome of public goods production (Brewer, 2003; Houston, 2006). Volunteering is defined as a contribution of time for the benefit of the needy or for solving some community problems (Wilson & Musick, 1997). It is work performed generally without monetary compensation and creates social outputs that would otherwise require paid resources (Freeman, 1997). This study limits its focus to formal volunteering that is, any contribution of unpaid time to the activities of organizations or established entities (Carson, 1999; Wilson & Musick, 1997). Although informal volunteering (volunteering not through a formal organization) is also a significant part of people’s lives, types of this activity are more vague and harder to measure compared with volunteering through formal organizations or established entities.

People volunteer for a number of reasons, including value expression, social networks, ego defense, or acquisition of skills and knowledge (Omoto & Snyder, 1995; Wilson, 2000). Despite various motivations for volunteering, the literature emphasizes the importance of values and beliefs in decision to volunteer (Wilson, 2000). Flanagan and his colleagues (1999, p. 149) find that volunteers rate working to improve their communities, aiding the less fortunate, and doing something for their country higher than those who do not volunteer. The positive link between volunteering and PSM can be found in the centrality of these prosocial values and beliefs behind both concepts.

Research findings often show higher volunteering rates among nonprofit employees than public employees (Lee & Wilkins, 2011; Rotolo & Wilson, 2006) although some find no difference between the two groups’ rates of volunteering (Houston, 2006). If the volunteering rate is higher among nonprofit workers, does this mean that nonprofit workers are demonstrating higher levels of PSM than public sector employees? Although the volunteering-PSM link is intuitive and the existing literature suggests a positive relationship between PSM and volunteering (Brewer, 2003; Houston, 2006), one aspect public administration scholars have ignored is that volunteering, as well as PSM, includes many heterogeneous types of activities.

Focusing on participation in volunteering as a homogenous activity provides a limited view of the motivations behind volunteering, because the term volunteering includes many different types of helping activities (Carson, 1999). Research suggests that volunteering with different types of organizations are not perfect substitutes with each other (Rossi, 2001; Sundeen, 1992; Wolff, Weisbrod, & Bird, 1993). For instance, Segal and Weisbrod (2002) find that tax changes and demographic shifts have different effects on volunteering in health, education, and religious organizations.

Provided that volunteering includes various forms of activities and that the concept of PSM also includes multiple aspects, a unidimensional PSM-volunteering link overlooks many possible explanations. This study aims to shed light on the distinctiveness in behavioral implications of PSM between government and nonprofit workers focusing on volunteering by each group. If government and nonprofit employees differ in dimensions of PSM, they will volunteer in kinds of organizations that reflect the PSM dimensions that are linked to their motivation. This study first examines whether one group is more or less likely to volunteer than the other in general. Next, it examines different patterns in their volunteering in various types of organizations.

sec.title: Data and Method
sec.p: Using the data from the Current Population Survey (CPS) September 2007 supplements, this study examines volunteering by employees in the public, nonprofit, and for-profit sectors, focusing particularly on the difference between public and nonprofit employees. The CPS is a monthly survey of a sample of 60,000 households conducted by the U.S. Census Bureau for the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). It is focused on the civilian, noninstitutional population aged 16 years and older. In addition to the basic labor force data, the September supplements of the CPS contain detailed information about individual volunteering including incidence of volunteering, hours of volunteering, and types of volunteer organizations and activities.

This study first examines the volunteering rates of employees in each sector using a binomial probit model. The binomial probit regression analyzes a two-way choice between participation and nonparticipation in volunteering. Next, this study employs the multinomial probit (MNP) regression to examine the patterns of employees’ participation in volunteering for different types of organizations. The MNP model allows more than two discrete, unordered outcomes, in this case different types of organizations where an individual volunteered. Various control variables are included in the model, including a person’s education, family situation, salary, household income, and other demographic characteristics such as gender, age, and race. The analysis results are weighted so that they reflect the total U.S. population.

sec.title: Dependent Variables
sec.p: The dependent variable in the binomial probit regression is whether an individual participated in volunteering of any kind. It takes the value of 1 if he or she participated in volunteering for the past 12 months, and 0 otherwise.

The dependent variable in the MNP regression is whether a person volunteered in each type of volunteer organization, and he or she can volunteer in one of four different types of volunteer organizations: religious, education, social and community, and other types of organizations.1 Therefore, an individual faces a five-way choice including no volunteering altogether. Although an individual may volunteer for more than one type of organization, this study focuses on the organizations where volunteers spent the most hours.

One potential problem is that participation in different types of volunteering may not be independently determined from each other. For instance, volunteering for religious organizations may influence the likelihood of volunteering for social and community associations, and vice versa. When there is a correlation among alternatives, the Irrelevance of Independent Alternatives (IIA) assumption may not hold. That is, introducing a third alternative may affect the relative odds between the two alternatives considered. This study estimates choice of the volunteering organization with an MNP model because it does not suffer from IIA violation, unlike a multinomial logit model (McCulloch, Polson, & Rossi, 2000; Nobile, 1998).

sec.title: Sector of Employment
sec.p: This study examines the patterns in volunteering by public, nonprofit, and for-profit employees2. Two dummy variables—one for working in the government sector and the other for working in the nonprofit sector—are included as the for-profit sector being the base (excluded) category.

sec.title: Industries
sec.p: If one works in an industry where opportunities for volunteering or needs for volunteer labor are more abundant than others, he or she will be more likely to volunteer. Therefore, the differing distribution of these industries across the sectors may affect differences in volunteering. Volunteers are most likely to work in education, health, and social services organizations (Segal & Weisbrod, 2002). Those industries, in turn, tend to be concentrated in the public and nonprofit sectors. For instance, “occupations that are known to produce many volunteers, such as school teachers, are almost entirely confined to the public sectors (Lewis & Frank, 2002, p. 396).” However, Clary and his colleagues (1996) find that volunteers satisfy different social goals and needs that are not being fulfilled in their paid work and home environment. Gibelman and Sweifach (2008), for instance, find that social workers are not major contributors of volunteer time because they believe that they gave enough through their jobs. In this sense, working in the above industries may discourage volunteering in such organizations or volunteering altogether. This study controls for working in the so-called “caring” industries, including education, health, and social services,3 as these organizations rely on volunteer labor more heavily than other types of organizations. This study first estimates a reduced model without industry control and a full model with industry control to see if the different distribution of caring industries across the sectors influences volunteering patterns in each sector.

sec.title: Gender
sec.p: The literature offers several reasons for higher rates of volunteering among women, including their greater availability of time and flexibility (Tiehen, 2000), higher levels of altruism and empathy (Donoghue, 2001; Wilson & Musick, 1997), as well as role-related norms and gender-specific socialization (Lyons, 1983; Tronto, 1987). Sectoral differences in the volunteer rate may be influenced by the different proportions of women in each sector as research finds women account for a majority of government and nonprofit workforce, especially in the nonprofit sector (Halpern, 2006; Independent Sector, 2002; Salamon & Sokolowski, 2006). As well as the gender gap in overall participation, research also suggests gender differences in specific volunteering activities (Lyons, 1983). A dummy variable for being female (1 if female and 0 otherwise) is included.

sec.title: Family Situation: Parental and Marital Status
sec.p: Research suggests that having children increases people’s likelihood for volunteering (Putnam, 2000; Wilson, 2000). Parents with school-aged children, in particular, experience an increase in their social capital through participation in parent–teacher organizations, sports organizations, and other types of involvement in their children’s activities (McNeal, 1998; Putnam, 2000; Wilson, 2000). The impact of children may vary by the nature of volunteer activity (Janoski & Wilson, 1995): Having children increases an individual’s participation in volunteering within education-related organizations, but it may not affect participation in other types of organizations. An individual’s social networks also expand because of marriage, and research findings indicate that married people are more likely to volunteer than those who are not married (Mesch, Rooney, Steinberg, & Denton, 2006; Sundeen, 1990). In this study, a person’s marital status and parental status (having children under 18) are included as controls.

sec.title: Age
sec.p: The relationship between age and volunteering can be explained by various changes in personal resources, including human, physical, and social. As an individual gets older, all social ties increase, however, these ties tend to decrease past retirement age. Physical strength decreases after the late 20s and tends to deteriorate after retirement age, which may well limit an older person’s participation in volunteer activities. However, research suggests the greater availability of time and the desire to substitute loss of paid work with volunteering may increase older adults’ participation (Okun, 1994 ). Overall, the literature suggests that an individual’s volunteering rate increases through middle age, reaching its peak at this stage (Menchik & Weisbrod, 1987; Schoenberg, 1980; Wilson & Musick, 1997). Research also finds that there is an age difference among employees of different sectors (Mirvis, 1992; Mirvis & Hackett, 1983), and the different distribution of workers’ age may affect volunteering across the sectors. Two variables—age and age2—are included to control the age effect on volunteering.

sec.title: Income
sec.p: National surveys find that higher income is a consistent predictor of volunteer participation (Cutler, 1980; Hodgkinson, Weitzman, Noga, & Gorski, 1992; Sundeen, 1992). Smith (1994) explains the positive association between income and volunteering with the “dominant status model.” He argues that individuals with a more dominant sociocultural status tend to participate more often in volunteer activities. However, some scholars suggest that higher opportunity costs of volunteering may discourage participation in volunteer activities (Freeman, 1997; Wolff et al., 1993). If salaries differ across the sectors (Leete, 2001; Preston 1989; Salamon & Sokolowski, 2006), the gap in nonprofit wages will affect employees’ participation in volunteer activities either positively or negatively. A logarithm of weekly earnings is included to account for income effect on volunteering.

sec.title: Race
sec.p: Research finds that Whites account for a greater percentage of the nonprofit workforce compared with other sectors (Lights, 2002). On the contrary, government agencies adopt policy-level initiatives for affirmative action and diversity, which may contribute to a higher level of diversity in its workforce. Surveys on volunteering report that racial and ethnic minorities tend to volunteer less than nonminorities (Bryant, Jeon-Slaughter, Kang, & Tax, 2003; Gallagher, 1994; Sundeen, 1992). Therefore, the differing distribution of races may affect the volunteer rate across the sectors. However, research suggests that the gap in volunteering between racial and ethnic groups disappears when controlling for one’s human and social capital (Conley, 2000; Musick, Wilson, & Bynum, 2000). A dummy variable for being White is included in the model.

sec.title: Education
sec.p: An individual’s level of education is one of the most consistent predictors of volunteering (McPherson & Rotolo, 1996; Putnam, 2000). Research finds the reasons for higher rates of volunteering among the educated in such factors as increased awareness of social problems, higher levels of empathy, and strong self-confidence (Brady, Verba, & Schlozman, 1995; Rosenthal, Feiring, & Lewis, 1998). The literature suggests that employees’ educational attainment differs across the public, nonprofit, and for-profit sectors (Johnston & Rudney, 1987; Mirvis, 1992), and this difference in education level may affect different rates of volunteering across the sectors. Five different levels of educational attainment are specified, including less than high school graduation, high school graduate or GED, some college or associate degree, college graduate, and graduate or professional degree.

sec.title: Work Hours
sec.p: Role overload theory (Markham & Bonjean, 1996) predicts a negative association between hours of paid work and volunteer hours. In contrast, Freeman (1997) finds a rough U-shaped relationship between work hours and volunteer hours. Studies report that nonprofit employees work fewer hours than government and for-profit workers in general (Preston, 1989), and the difference in paid work hours may affect the likelihood of volunteering across the sectors. The number of work hours per week is included in the model.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 provides descriptive statistics of 13,6644 employees across the for-profit, public, and nonprofit sectors. The table shows that nonprofit employees have the highest rate of volunteering (39.6%) followed by public employees and for-profit employees (34.7% and 21.4%, respectively). The order of nonprofit, public, and for-profit remains across different types of volunteering organizations, except for educational organizations. Government employees volunteer at a higher rate than nonprofit employees in educational organizations.

Table 1 also shows that the nonprofit sector is more female-dominated and White-dominated and its employees work less hours and earn smaller incomes than employees of the public sector, which all can contribute to higher rate of volunteering in the sector. However, public sector workers are more likely to have graduate education, to be married, and to have children than nonprofit employees. These characteristics also positively affect the likelihood of volunteering, and they are controlled in the regression model accordingly.

The binomial probit results in Table 2 indicate that nonprofit employees are more likely to volunteer than public sector workers with or without industry control. Without industry control, public workers are 6.8% more likely and nonprofit workers are 10.9% more likely to volunteer than for-profit employees. After industry control, nonprofit workers are 11.7% and government workers are 5.5% more likely to volunteer than for-profit ones. In terms of overall volunteering, nonprofit workers seem to walk further the walk of PSM.5

Next, this study tests if this pattern of “nonprofit>public>for-profit” remains across different types of organizations using the MNP model. Table 3 shows the regression coefficients and Table 4 shows marginal effects after MNP regression. Marginal effect measures the change in the probability of volunteering in each type of organization as each independent variable changes by one unity while all other variables are kept at their means. In the reduced model (with no industry control), shown in the top rows in Table 4, nonprofit workers are 5.4% more likely and public employees are 2.4% more likely to volunteer in religious organizations than their for-profit counterparts. In educational organizations, nonprofit workers are not more likely to volunteer than for-profit workers, while public workers are 2.8% more likely to do so when compared with for-profit employees. In social and community organizations, nonprofit workers are 1.6% more likely to volunteer than for-profit workers but there is no difference between public and for-profit employees. In all other types of organizations, nonprofit workers are 2.6% more likely and government workers are 1.6% more likely to volunteer than for-profit employees.

When compared with overall participation in volunteering, two findings show noticeable differences. First, government employees are more likely to volunteer in educational organizations than nonprofit employees, while nonprofit employees are not different from for-profit workers. Second, government workers are not different from their for-profit counterparts in terms of volunteering in social and community organizations. The differing patterns in volunteer participation may originate from the distribution of industries between the public and nonprofit sectors. More than 8 out of 10 nonprofit employees work in health (55%), education (14%), or social assistance organizations (13%; Independent Sector, 2007; Salamon & Sokolowski, 2006). A majority of government jobs are also distributed in schools and libraries (Kettl & Fesler, 2005). These so-called caring industries have higher demand for volunteers. Therefore, employment in such organizations may increase the likelihood for workers to be asked to volunteer within their own organization. Differing distribution of such industries in the public and nonprofit sector will consequently affect the type of volunteer organization. To control for the effect of industry distribution across the sectors, the full model includes control for working in education, health, and social services.

The bottom rows in Tables 3 and 4 show the MNP estimation results and marginal effects after controlling for working in education, health, and social service industries. The findings indicate that even after industry control, nonprofit employees are still more likely to volunteer for religious and social/community organizations than for-profit and government workers. There is no difference in the likelihood of volunteering in educational organizations between nonprofit and for-profit employees. Government workers are more likely to volunteer for educational institutions than both nonprofit and business workers, and this is not just because they work in the education industry. Although working in education increases the likelihood for volunteering to such types of organizations by 2.8%, government employees are still 1.3% more likely to be volunteers in such organizations than their for-profit and nonprofit counterparts. Working in health and social services has negative impacts on volunteering for educational and social/community organizations and no impact on volunteering in all other types of organizations. The results also show that the difference between public and nonprofit employees in terms of their likelihood to volunteer for other types of organization disappears after industry control.

In summary, the findings suggest that public and nonprofit workers volunteer at a higher rate than for-profit workers do. When looking at specific types of volunteer organizations, however, differing patterns exist between public and nonprofit employees. Nonprofit workers are more likely to volunteer than public workers for religious and social community organizations. Public employees are not different from for-profit workers in terms of volunteering in social and community organizations. However, government workers are more likely to volunteer in educational organizations than employees in the nonprofit sector and in the for-profit sector. Nonprofit workers are not more likely to volunteer in these organizations than their for-profit counterparts.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: The findings of this study indicate that different patterns exist in volunteering by public and nonprofit employees. In a Black-or-White world of volunteering, nonprofit workers volunteer at a higher rate, therefore, they “walk further the walk of PSM.” However, the results suggest that this dichotomous approach may be limited, because in a multicolored world of volunteering in different types of organizations, nonprofit workers are more likely to volunteer in religious and social/community organizations, while public workers are more likely to volunteer in educational organizations. This study makes another unique contribution to existing literature as it examines if varying patterns of volunteering are because of the different industry structure across the sectors. Although differences in industry structure create some of the discrepancies in volunteering activities, the nonprofit-social/community and religious volunteering and public-educational volunteering patterns still remain the same.6

The CPS does not contain questions on individuals’ motivations, and because of this limitation in data, this study does not test how specific dimensions of PSM are linked to different types of volunteering organizations. However, this study provides empirical evidence that behavioral implications of PSM differ between public and nonprofit employees. The literature suggests that selecting individuals with norms consistent with PSM is one of the powerful management tools for increasing organizational performance in government agencies (Brehm & Gates, 1997; Houston, 2006). Hence, understanding public-nonprofit differences in PSM will contribute to enhancing organizational performance in both the public and nonprofit sectors by helping organizations better manage their employees.

The findings in this study suggest that behavioral implications of PSM may be better understood by examining the relationship between volunteering and different dimensions of PSM. The current dichotomous approach to research on PSM’s effects on volunteering does not take into consideration that there are differing patterns of volunteer participation between government and nonprofit employees. Future research should examine how different dimensions of PSM are associated with volunteering within various types of organizations and with different volunteer activities. Comprehensive surveys of employee motivation in terms of the multiple dimensions of PSM and their volunteer activities may reveal a link between PSM and prosocial behavior.

This study adopts the CPS classification of industries as well as its typology of volunteer organizations. One should interpret the results with caution because the CPS classification may combine more than two distinctive categories into one or categorize a group of closely related organizations and industries into multiple types. Nevertheless, it is not very likely that categorization causes a bias in other coefficient estimates as the analysis shows consistent patterns in volunteer behaviors among employees in the public, for-profit, and nonprofit sectors with or without industry control.

As much as an individual’s PSM affects career choices across sectors (Perry & Wise, 1990), employment in a certain sector may also affect one’s PSM (Moynihan & Pandey, 2007). Although postemployment socialization may influence behavioral differences in volunteering, this study is not able to control for socialization effects on PSM given the cross-sectional data structure. In other words, it is not clear to what extent the behavioral differences are inherent in workers and to what extent they were socialized in particular ways depending on their employment sector. Future research may examine organizational effects on development of different dimensions of PSM and its behavioral implication on employees with panel data.

ack.p: The author is grateful to the reviewers and the editors for their insightful and constructive comments on the article. She also thanks Dr. David Houston for his helpful comments.

fn.p: An earlier version of this article was presented at the American Society for Public Administration conference, at San Jose, CA, April 11, 2010.
The author declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
The author received no financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article.
Organization typology follows the CPS classification.
Volunteering by the self-employed and those who are not in labor force is outside of the focus of this study.
Categorization of industries in this study follows the CPS industry classification.

Every household that enters the CPS is interviewed each month for 4 months, then ignored for 8 months, and interviewed again for 4 more months. Questions on weekly earnings are asked only at households in their fourth and eighth interview. In other words, CPS surveys 6,400 households every month on basic labor force information, and usual weekly hours/earning questions are asked only to one fourth of the households (called outgoing rotation group) each month. Since the model includes an individual’s weekly earning, only onefourth is included in the sample. Also, this study examines volunteering by paid employees in three sectors, which excludes those who are self-employed or not in labor force. Because of these reasons, the final sample has N of 13,664.
The results did not change when having the nonprofit worker as the base category.

Some possible explanations can be found in the literature. For instance, Lee and Wilkins (2011) find the opportunity to serve the public and public interests was a more important part of PSM of public workers compared with PSM of nonprofit workers. Other research reports that nonprofit workers have more positive attitudes toward the influence of religion than government workers (Houston & Cartwright, 2007; Houston, Freeman, & Feldman, 2008). In their comparison of volunteers in public and nonprofit human service agencies, Cnaan and Goldberg-Glen (1990) find that volunteers in nonprofit organizations scored higher on the liking people scale than public agency volunteers, while there is no significant difference in their scores on other social-psychological traits.

BradyH. E. VerbaS. SchlozmanK. L. (1995). Beyond SES: A resource model of political participation. American Political Science Review, 89, 271-294.
BrehmJ. GatesS. (1997). Working, shirking, and sabotage. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press.
BrewerG. A. (2003). Building social capital: Civic attitudes and behavior of public servants. Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory, 13(1), 5-26.
BrewerG. A. SeldenS. C. (1998). Whistle blowers in the federal civil service: New evidence of the public service ethic. Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory, 8, 413-440.
